questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with recurrent epistaxis, abdominal distension, and splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and reduced glucocerebrosidase enzyme activity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-month-old infant presents with developmental delay, coarse facial features, and hepatosplenomegaly. Ophthalmological examination reveals a cherry-red spot on the macula. X-rays show skeletal dysplasia with vertebral abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
• Progressive neurodegeneration
  • Developmental delay or regression
  • Seizures
  • Visceromegaly (enlarged liver and spleen)
  • Coarse facial features
  • Cherry-red spot on the macula
  • Skeletal abnormalities
  • Hypotonia

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with hepatosplenomegaly, progressive neurological deterioration, and lung involvement. Foam cells are found in the bone marrow, and genetic testing reveals a mutation in the SMPD1 gene. What disease is the child suffering from?

A 7-month-old infant presents with developmental regression, loss of head control, spasticity, and an exaggerated startle response. The infant is diagnosed with Tay-Sachs disease. Which of the following regarding this condition is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern

questions.explanation:
Features

Description

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive (Option A)

Cause

Deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme (Option B)

Accumulation

GM2 ganglioside in ganglion cells and neurons

Clinical Manifestations
  • Initial symptoms include loss of head control, inability to sit, exaggerated startle response to sound, and a disproportionately large head.
  • Progressive features include spasticity, deafness, and blindness.
  • Not associated with organomegaly.

Fundus Finding

Cherry-red spot (Option C) is caused by GM2 ganglioside accumulation in the ganglion cells of the retina, creating a contrast with the normal red fovea.

questions.text: Match the following types of mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) with their corresponding enzyme deficiencies: Types of MPS Enzyme deficiencies 1.MPS I a. N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfatase 2.MPS II b. Iduronate-2-sulfatase 3.MPS IV c. Alpha-L-iduronidase 4.MPS VI d. Arylsulfatase B
questions.explanation:
MPS Type

MPS I (Hurler syndrome)

MPS II (Hunter syndrome)

MPS IV (Morquio syndrome)

MPS VI (Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome)

Enzyme Deficiency

Alpha-L Iduronidase

MPS 1= Alpha LID

Iduronate-2-sulfatase

N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfatase

Arylsulfatase B

Gene

IDUA

IDS

GALNS (Type A)

GLB1 (Type B)

ARSB

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

X-linked recessive (Males- Hunters- No corneal clouding (Clear vision for hunting))

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive

Primary GAGs Accumulated

Heparan sulfate, Dermatan sulfate

Heparan sulfate, Dermatan sulfate

Keratan sulfate, Chondroitin-6-sulfate

Dermatan sulfate

Types

Three subtypes:

  • Hurler Syndrome: Severe form, Type Ia.
  • Hurler-Scheie Syndrome: Intermediate form, Type Ia.
  • Scheie Syndrome: Attenuated form, Type Ib.
  

Two subtypes:

  • Type A (more common)
  • Type B
  

Features
  • Doll like facies
  • Developmental delay
  • Organomegaly
  • Skeletal abnormalities
  • Corneal clouding
  • Primarily affects males
  • It is the same clinically as Hurler except there is no corneal clouding and peppble-like skin present.
  • Skeletal dysplasia
  • Short stature
  • Joint hypermobility
  • Corneal clouding
  • Preserved intelligence
  • Variable progression rate
  • Coarse facial features
  • Skeletal abnormalities
  • Heart valve problems
  • Normal intelligence

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Hunter Syndrome (MPS-II)?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Hunter Syndrome (MPS-II)

Hurler Syndrome (MPS-I)

Gene/Enzyme Deficiency

Iduronate sulfatase (IDS)

α-L-iduronidase

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Autosomal recessive

Corneal Clouding

Absent

Present

Coarse Facial Features

Present

Present

Short Stature

Dysostosis Multiplex

Joint Stiffness

Intellectual Disability

Mild to moderate, usually less severe than Hurler syndrome

Severe

Hepatosplenomegaly

Present

Present

Skeletal Dysplasia

Hearing Loss

Life Expectancy

Variable, often longer than Hurler syndrome

Usually fatal before 10 years of age

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with recurrent burning pain in his hands and feet, exacerbated by exercise. He has dark red spots on his skin, particularly on his lower back and thighs, and experiences visual disturbances. Laboratory evaluation revealed uremia. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Fabry’s disease

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Deficient Enzyme

α-galactosidase A (α-gal A)

Accumulated Substance

Globotriaosylceramide (GL-3)

Affected Cells

Vascular endothelium, smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, renal podocytes

Common Clinical Features
  • Angiokeratomas (telangiectatic skin lesions)
 
  • Hypohidrosis (reduced sweating)
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities
  • Painful acroparesthesias (burning sensations in extremities)

Complications
  • Kidney failure (proteinuria)
  • Heart disease (left ventricular hypertrophy, coronary artery disease, valvular infiltrative myopathy)
  • Stroke

Treatment
  • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT)
  • Management of neuropathic pain

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is diagnosed with a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) based on genetic testing. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

Cause

Deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT)

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Variants
  • Classic Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Undetectable HPRT levels.
  • Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome: Partial HPRT deficiency with variable neurological dysfunction.

Clinical Features
  • Self-injurious behaviour: Biting lips, fingers, tongue; begins with tooth eruption.
  • Cognitive impairment: Intellectual disability ranging from mild to severe.
  • Movement disorder: Starts with hypotonia, progresses to dystonia, choreoathetosis, oromandibular dystonia, and inspiratory stridor.
  • Oculomotor apraxia: Difficulty controlling eye movements.
  • Dysarthric speech: Difficulty speaking clearly.

Complications
  • Hyperuricemia: Causes gout and kidney stones.
  • Neurological symptoms: Abnormalities in the dopamine system, reduced dopamine transporters.

Treatment
  • Allopurinol: Reduces uric acid levels and manages hyperuricemia.
  • Symptom management: Controls movement disorders and self-injurious behaviours.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents with developmental delay, hypotonia, and recurrent myoclonic seizures. On examination, he is found to have hypopigmented skin, kinky hair and a distinctive facial appearance with a depressed nasal bridge. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Deficiency of the enzyme lysyl oxidase

questions.explanation:
Menkes Disease (Kinky Hair Disease)

Inheritance

X-linked recessive and primarily affects males (Option D)

Affected Gene

ATP7A (codes for copper-transporting P-type ATPase)

Gene Location

Xq21.1

Pathophysiology

Deficiency in copper absorption and transport, copper accumulation in some tissues and deficiency in others

Clinical Features
  • Hypothermia
  • Hypotonia
  • Generalised myoclonic seizures
  • Distinctive facies (chubby cheeks, depressed nasal bridge)
  • Kinky, colourless, brittle hair (trichorrhexis nodosa, pili torti)
  • Hypopigmentation
  • Feeding difficulties (failure to thrive)
  • Severe cognitive impairment (optic atrophy)
  • Neuropathologic changes (tortuous degeneration of grey matter, cerebellar changes)

Severity

Progressive and often fatal by age three if untreated.

Treatment

Early initiation of copper-histidinase therapy within the first six weeks of life.

Aspects

Menkes Disease

Wilson’s Disease

Inheritance

X-linked recessive

Autosomal recessive

Affected Gene

ATP7A (Xq21.1)

ATP7B (chromosome 13)

Pathophysiology

Copper deficiency due to impaired absorption/transport

Copper accumulation due to impaired transport

Clinical Features

Kinky hair, hypopigmentation, myoclonic seizures

Hepatomegaly, Jaundice, Kayser-Fleischer rings, tremors

Diagnosis

Clinical features, copper studies, gene testing
  • Low serum ceruloplasmin
  • Elevated 24-hour urinary copper excretion
  • Liver biopsy

Treatment

Copper-histidinase therapy within six weeks of life

Chelation (penicillamine), Zinc therapy, Liver transplant

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with abdominal distension, failure to thrive, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal severe adrenal insufficiency and elevated cholesteryl esters. A liver biopsy shows lipid accumulation in lysosomes. Which genetic mutation is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Wolman Disease

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Causing Gene

LIPA gene (located on chromosome 10q23.2-23.3)

Enzyme Deficiency

Lysosomal acid lipase (LAL)

Function of Enzyme

Breakdown of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides in endo-lysosomes

Pathophysiology

Accumulation of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides in histiocytic foam cells, leading to organ failure.

Onset of Symptoms

Typically, within the first few weeks of life

Clinical Features
  • Failure to thrive
  • Relentless vomiting
  • Abdominal distension
  • Steatorrhea (due to lymphatic obstruction caused by lipid accumulation in the small intestine)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

Adrenal Insufficiency

Characterised by subcapsular adrenal calcification due to insufficient free cholesterol for steroidogenesis.

Prognosis

Death usually occurs within the first year of life

Diagnosis

Imaging showing adrenal calcification and genetic testing for mutations in the LIPA gene.
